story:
There’s a new biotech threat coming from Silicon Valley: a private biotech company has hijacked that other crowd funding platform Kickstarter.com in a plan to release hundreds of thousands of glowing synthetic organisms made with an extreme genetic engineering technology called Synthetic Biology.

Having racked up over $400,000 on their crowdfunding drive the perpetrators of this proposed genetic pollution intend to pull off the first ever intentional release of syntehtic biology-derived organism without any oversight, monitoring or regulation. This would set a terrible and dangerous precedent.

To kick back we are doing a little crowdfunding jujitsu. ETC Group has launched the Kickstopper campaign. To start we have launched a petition and now need to raise the money for a long term campaign to stop the biohackers in their tracks. And as part of it we are going to make a comic book - and a bit of history too.

Join us in saving the word from Synthetic biology pollution. Become a backer of the Kickstopper campaign.

 

 A Novel Biotech Threat:

 It sounds crazy but it's not fiction: three grinning biohackers from a private biotech company associated with Silicon Valley's ultra-libertarian 'Singularity University’ recently landed on Kickstarter's 'most popular' list by promising to spread synthetic organisms across the USA; specifically, to mail packets of bio-engineered seeds to whoever paid them forty bucks online. The seeds, which they said would likely grow into 'glowing plants' (after all, ‘biology is complicated,’ admit the masterminds) would be the viable and reproducing products of a controversial new technology called ‘Synthetic Biology’ – a field that aims to build artificial life-forms from scratch. A field that has never had a deliberate release into the environment before. 


TheNew York Times portrait of the 'Glowing Plants' biohackers

 

Syn What?

 Synthetic Biology (or 'syn bio') can best be described as 'extreme genetic engineering'. it involves designing new strands of DNA moilecules  on a computer and then printing artificial DNA and engineering it into living things  to hijack the workings of a natural organism.  Syn Bio goes beyond the already considerable concerns people have about 'transgenic' genetic engineering and raises further hard-to-assess ecological risks, significant bio-weapons potential and, in the hands of industry, threats to the livelihoods of some of the world’s poorest farmers. Billions of dollars from oil, pharma, chemical and agribusiness firms are flowing into the field portending a new round of corporate power grabs on the stuff of life.


Read the ETC Group’sfull report on Synthetic Biology

 

Risks. Even as the ‘glowing plants’ Kickstarter campaign launched, ethicists from Oxford University released a report that branded Syn Bio one of the biggest 'existential risks'to the human species. It is just the latest in a parade of pronouncements from expert groups  – including from thePresident’s Bioethics Commission, government reps at theUN Biodiversity Convention, anEU expert group, the insurance industry and many others. The current consensus is that no synthetic organisms should be released into the environment without 'precaution,' 'prudent vigilance,' regulation, monitoring and other sober and sensible safeguards - A consensus that the 'glowing plant' biohackers are willfully ignoring. 

 

Growing Concern

While hundreds of thousands of Americans are taking part in a popular movement to stop – or at the very least, label – the first generation of biotech seeds and plants,111 organizations from around the world have called for a moratorium on this next generation of biotech organisms.

Read theThe Principles for the Oversight of Synthetic Biology issued by a coalition of 111 organizations

 

Evading Oversight. 

The biohackers insist they are totally within their rights to spread bio-engineered seeds from coast to coast. They claim that the US Department of Agriculture has advised them they can avoid regulatory oversight if they used a particular genetic engineering technique called the gene gun. This allows them toexploit a controversial loophole in the lawcarved out by big biotech firms. After all the official pieties about establishing proper oversight of synthetic biology and not rushing ahead with environmental release, the US government appears ready to avert its eyes.

The Glowing plant project think they can avoid all regulation and caution by crowdfunding their project on Kickstarter. They didn’t count on us kicking back.

 

Kickstarter's Role

Incredibly, Kickstarter turns out to be the only entity to have subjected this novel Syn Bio pollution project to any kind of review. Kickstarter has itsown ethical guidelines that are so specific they exclude the posting of projects involving 'sunglasses' or 'bath products,' yet promoting the world’s first uncontrolled, unmonitored and unregulated release of synthetic organisms apparently didn’t raise any red flags at Kickstarter HQ.

We wrote to Kickstarter at length to ask them to de-list the Glowing Plants project . They sent us a dismissive one line reply. We even submitted this crowdfunding campaign to them - they declined it. We have now launched a petition asking them to not allow engineered organisms to be released through their platform. So far they refuse to discuss their support for the project. Kickstarter continues to host the Glowing Plants project and on 7th June will give over 400,000 in funding over to the Glowing plants guys, implicitly blessing the project. Kickstarter was built to help struggling artists, not give corporate biohackers with risky technologies a blank cheque to threaten our ecosystems. We encourage Kickstarter to its roots and disassociate itself from this project.

 

Kicking back!

ETC Groupis a tiny (eight person) non-profit international civil society research group. We don't have the financial resources or rich backers that Genome Compiler Corp. has, but we do have a good track record in stopping destructive biotech projects. 

 We decided if the biohackers can hijack a Kickstarter campaign to release their glowtesque synthetic biology plants and crowdfund for it, then maybe there are quite a few sensible folks who would be willing to pitch in to fund the counter-campaign to stuff the genetically engineered genie back in the bottle – or at least ensure it never makes it out of the glowing plant lab. So was born the idea of the counter-Kickstarter Project –the Kickstopper. Roll the crowdfunding wars.

As the 'glowing plants' story unfolds, we will be doing everything we can to change the plot. With your help we will mount asuccesful campaign to stop the syn bio seeds We will work to write a happy ending where no Syn Bio seeds leave the lab, where governments see sense and decide to step in. To write that real story, we will work with artists, scientists, gardeners, farmers, activists, lawyers, students, teachers, government officials, UN delegates, journalists and a growing coalition of civil society groups.

We will also  publish a historic comic book about exactly how we stopped them - and we can send that to you as a backer of this campaign The comic book will include the work of  a talented collection of radical graphic artists, includingShtig,Jordan Worley,Zeph Fishlyn,David Nishizaki,Mensen, Ethan Heitner, in addition to other artists associated withWorld War 3 Illustrated and theBeehive Design Collective.

By backing this Kickstopper campaign, you will not only fund the book, but will also be part of stopping the Syn Bio pollution itself – helping write (and draw) a little bit of history while protecting the future.

 

Voices of Support:

 

Dr. Vandana Shiva lends support to the Kickstopper project.

** A huge thanks toJocelyne Clarke and Martin Duckworth, social justice film-makers extraordinaire for producing and filming our video.

Help Spread the Word about Kickstopper

·Like ETC Group on Facebook (http://www.facebook.com/theetcgroup)

·Email your friends about the Kickstopper Project: (http://www.etcgroup.org/kickstopper)

- Sign the petition to ask Kickstarter to not allow bioengineered organisms: http://www.avaaz.org/en/petition/Tell_Kickstarter_not_to_allow_bioengineered_organisms

Please back the project and tell everyone you know to do likewise – help spread the word and stop the release of Synthetic Organisms.

Thank You For Your Support.

 

Risks and challenges

The biggest risk is that we do nothing and let the synthetic biologists move ahead with releasing hundreds of thousands of syn bio seeds, setting an eerily glowing precedent that many other commercial biotech firms and informal biohackers alike will follow. If that happens, our story won’t have a happy ending.

 

The biggest challenge will be the organized money and power behind the synthetic biologists pushing their twisted storyline. Literally, billions of dollars are flowing into synthetic biology from companies such as Monsanto, BP, Shell, Cargill, DuPont, Dow, Total and Chevron. The Glowing Plants biohackers are associated with a commercial company, Genome Compiler Corporation, and some of their backers have deep pockets to fund a PR war. Indeed they have hired a professional PR company to run their Kickstarter campaign.

 

Indeed, the Glowing Plants Project itself is a PR salvo, as explained by financial guy Antony Evans: "The main goal of our project is to inspire people and awaken them to the potentials of this technology…Kickstarter is a great way of getting publicity around the capabilities of this technology." The ability of these commercial players to change and control the ending of the story should not be underestimated.

 

Thankfully, ETC Group has a good track record – in the past we have helped achieve international moratoriums on Terminator seeds (genetically engineered to be sterile) and on geoengineering techniques (attempts to modify planetary systems to hack the climate), including ocean fertilization. We have been around a long time and have lots of good friends to call on – you'll meet them in the pages of the book. They also passionately want to see a good ending to the story. And, of course, we're asking you to not just fund and read the result of this publishing project, but to participate in how the plot line unfurls.

story:
Home Grown Electricty

No mining and burning dirty coal, No fracking for natural gas, No harsh carbon emissions.Our “genius” farmer friend has spent years developing a renewable hybrid feedstock that when dried, burns completely clean to generate electricity. It renews itself every 24 hours, and can be easily processed to make natural gas, biodiesel, and also high protein feed for livestock, chickens, and even our pets. He has taken on huge debt to develop this process, patent it, and to get all the local, state, and federal approvals necessary to get this to market.We are almost there, but we need $25,000 for licensing fees. If we surpass our goal, the additional funds will go toward the engineering, permitting and legal fees necessary to get the traditional funding to build our first farm/plant on our family’s property.


Our Hopes and Dreams

We have high hopes. In ten years we want to see 50% of the electricity generated in the USA - home grown. Our method of producing energy will revitalize the farming industry, greatly reduce the carbon footprint, lower our dependence on foreign oil, and create a whole new industry of clean, healthy jobs.

Our way to give back is if we surpass our goal, and eventually get the funding to build our energy farm, we will donate the equal amount of your contributions to the Humane Society and the American Cancer Society.

 

More Info

We don’t mean to be “Secret Sam” about this, but unfortunately we do not have International patents in place yet, so all of the information about how we will do this is proprietary for now. However I can tell you that our feedstock is grown in greenhouses and it takes about 2 acres of greenhouses to generate 1MW of electricity. The generators that burn the feedstock will be situated under power lines and the energy produced will be fed, in most cases, directly into the grid or a gas pipeline. The process has been vetted by major universities and has been given a big green “Thumbs Up”.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Boy - do we ever understand tight budgets! If you can't contribute, please help us spread the word.

story:
Join Us to Activate Public Space, One School at a Time

People for Parks is a Los Angeles based 501 c3  non-profit organization working towards the day when every child in Los Angeles lives within walking distance of a safe park.  We do this by finding creative solutions to the problem of park-scarcity, adding new park space in dense, under-resourced neighborhoods and  implementing intervention programs to make existing parks safer. Please visit our website! http://www.peopleforparks.org

The Need: Los Angeles is one of the most under-parked cities in the US, with only 33% of kids living near a park (97% of kids in Boston live within ¼ mile of a park; in New York City, 91% do and in San Diego that number is 60%).  Park scarcity is even more severe in lower-income neighborhoods of our city.  Hollywood’s population of 85,489 people, for example, lives in a 3.51 square mile area.  This means 0.09 acres of park space for every 1,000 residents.  The national averages range from 6.25 to 10.5 acres per 1000 residents. LA averages 4.2.  Without opportunities for safe, outdoor recreation, children in high crime, over-populated areas of LA face the danger of playing in the streets during summer and weekends, when traditional after-school programming is unavailable.  The alternative is staying  at home and facing the health and wellness risks associated with limited physical activity. 

The Opportunity – Community School Parks:

Of LAUSD’s 550 elementary and middle schools, 400 are located within communities in urgent need of a park. Most of these schools contain play spaces that go unused on weekends and holidays. This is where Community School Parks or CSPs come in. CSPs are active school-site playgrounds that are open to the community during non-school hours. The Community School Park is based on the principle that public schoolyards can function as shared recreational facilities that both reinforce children’s health and fitness and strengthen entire communities.   Given that schools are evenly spaced and located within walking distance of most youth in LA, CSPs are also an efficient and cost effective way to give kids in dense regions of our city the space they need to play, grow and learn.  

We’ve worked very closely with city and county officials and with LAUSD – the second largest landowner in Los Angles - to replace asphalt-covered blacktops and empty sport fields with state-of-the-art play spaces on public school grounds. LAUSD after-school enrichment staff members regularly maintain these parks’ safety and supervision according to district guidelines.   So far, we’ve developed two beautiful Community School Parks: one at Trinity Elementary School in South LA and another at Vine Elementary School in Hollywood. As you can see in the video above and in parents' stories below, both parks have become major hubs for recreation, celebration and community-building. 

Some of our communities' recent testimonials...

“I love this park because I can run free.” - Zia W., 4 years old

“We come here every Saturday to shoot hoops and talk about the game.” - Joshua M., 5th grade

“I get really sad when the park is closed.  My favorite thing to do here is arts and crafts” - Gisele S., 3rd Grade

“This is the only park we have in this neighborhood.  Everything else is driving distance, and I don’t have a car (…) When the park first opened, my daughter was really shy.  She never wanted to leave my side.  Now that she’s had the opportunity to play and do arts and crafts with the other kids, she’s really come out of her shell.” -  Teresa S., parent

“The parents have come to enjoy it as much as the kids do.  One of our moms teaches sewing right here at the picnic tables.  A dad started a tradition of teaching the kids about recycling. Another mom hosted a Filipino culture day.” - Maria M., parent

“This is the only park that’s in walking distance from us.  Coming to this park on the weekends is like going to a friend’s backyard to sit and talk.  The kids love it and it’s a nice decompression time for the parents (…)The staff members lovingly assist our kids with crafts, sports and other physical fitness games. (…) I feel like I can really let my guard down at this park because it’s removed from the street.  It takes the stress off me.” -  Jessica W., parent

“If we don’t bring them to the park, the kids just watch TV or play video games at home. Our place is really small. If I don’t bring her to the park, she bounces off the walls.” -  Maritza R., parent

Our Campaign: Fund Community School Parks!

Over the last two years, our Community School Parks thrived, but since the beginning of 2015, due to recent funding cuts, we have not been able to reopen these parks.

http://beverlypress.com/2014/12/vine-street-elementary-park-partnership-in-peril/

We are coming to you to help us reopen our Community School Parks at Trinity and Vine Elementary Schools.  The process is inexpensive and easy.  It costs just about $6000 dollars to keep one school park open every Saturday for one year.  This means $12,000 to open both parks one day a week (which is our goal for this campaign) and $24,000 to keep both parks open all weekend (which is our long-term goal).  These funds pay for a LAUSD youth specialist or district-approved parent representative to open and close the gates and keep the site supervised. This dollar amount also pays for supplies and custodial time.
 

If we raise over $12,000, we’ll extend hours, so that these parks stay open as much as possible.  If we make it to $60,000, we can keep both parks open on the weekends and after school every day all year!

If this campaign is really successful, all donations over $60k will go towards funding our Community School Park Incubator.  What is this? Based on the success of our two pilot sites, our organization is now launching the Community School Park Incubator Program wherein we train principals, parents and other community members on Community School Park development, safety and maintenance as well as district policy and civic engagement.  We want children, youth, families and their neighbors to have the skills and resources needed to transform their school sites into sustainable neighborhood parks of their own.

Your tax-deductible donations will not only reopen parks in two communities that desperately need them.  It will also show that through grassroots support, anyone can fund a project like this in their community, regardless of their zip code.  That is, if people are provided the right resources, are organized and receive a helping hand by people like YOU, they can come together to reinvigorate public school yards.  


Thank you for your support!


Sincerely, 

Larry Watts, President - People for Parks


If you have any questions, please contact: 

Anna Gruben at annagruben@peopleforparks.org or 877.776.9630
story_txt:
Join Us to Activate Public Space, One School at a Time
People for Parks is a Los Angeles based 501 c3  non-profit organization working
towards the day when every child in Los Angeles lives within walking distance
of a safe park.  We do this by finding creative solutions to the problem
of park-scarcity, adding new park space in dense, under-resourced neighborhoods
and  implementing intervention programs to make existing parks safer.
Please visit our website! http://www.peopleforparks.org
The Need: Los Angeles is one of the most under-parked cities in the US, with
only 33% of kids living near a park (97% of kids in Boston live within ¼ mile
of a park; in New York City, 91% do and in San Diego that number is 60%). 
Park scarcity is even more severe in lower-income neighborhoods of our
city.  Hollywood’s population of 85,489 people, for example, lives in a
3.51 square mile area.  This means 0.09 acres of park space for every
1,000 residents.  The national averages range from 6.25 to 10.5 acres per
1000 residents. LA averages 4.2.  Without opportunities for safe, outdoor
recreation, children in high crime, over-populated areas of LA face the danger
of playing in the streets during summer and weekends, when traditional
after-school programming is unavailable.  The alternative is staying
 at home and facing the health and wellness risks associated with limited
physical activity. 

The Opportunity – Community School Parks:
Of LAUSD’s 550 elementary and middle
schools, 400 are located within communities in urgent need of a park. Most of these schools contain play spaces that go unused on weekends and
holidays. This is where Community School Parks or CSPs come in. CSPs are active school-site playgrounds that are open to the community
during non-school hours. The Community School Park is based on the
principle that public schoolyards can function as shared recreational
facilities that both reinforce children’s health and fitness and strengthen
entire communities.   Given that schools are evenly spaced and located
within walking distance of most youth in LA, CSPs are also an efficient and

with the other kids, she’s really come out of her shell.” -  Teresa S.,
parent
“The parents have come to enjoy it as much as the kids do.  One of

“This is the only park that’s in walking distance from us.  Coming

(…)The staff members lovingly assist our kids with crafts, sports and

story:
Help the people have their say on climate change at the People's Climate March and Gathering in Edinburgh

We are a group of 23 enthusiastic volunteers who are organising the People's Climate March & Gathering in Edinburgh.

This is part of the largest global mobilisation about climate change in history which will take place on 21st September 2014. The march is a grassroots event organised by people for the people and not a platform for political parties.

The message we want to send out is that the people want Action, Not Words from the Climate Change Summit taking place in New York the week starting 23rd September as well as from the summits following it in Lima and Paris.

International summits and talks have been going on for decades but hardly anything has come out of these. We want people from all walks of life to take part in the march and show politicians that we are united on climate issues regardless of our social, political or religious background.

Because we believe in environmentally friendly actions, we will be using recyclable materials to create most of our visual displays, however we do need some funding to buy what we cannot find for free.

We need financial support to:

1.create and print advertising materials for the event.

2.to hire a public address sound system

3.to pay a photographer to document the event in digital photographs and film

4.to buy any other materials that we cannot find for free and create banners, placards and other visual displays for the event

Photos and video recordings will be published along with those from other events world wide to raise global awareness in the media of the importance of taking action on climate issues.

We would like this to be a participatory event and intend to make it possible for those attending to share their thoughts and reflections on climate issues.

We have created a Facebook page for the Edinburgh March People's Climate March & Gathering Edinburgh Facebook event where people can join the event and a blog  People's Climate March & Gathering Edinburgh blog  where people can read more about the event and the issues at stake.

Further details of our plans for the day will be posted online as they take shape.

story:
Hello fellow honey bee advocates! 
 

My name is Hilary Kearney and I am an educator, beekeeper and entrepreneur. My business Girl Next Door Honey educates hundreds of kids each year and I want to help you do the same! 

I created The Story of Bees game originally to enrich my own classroom presentations and kids' workshops. I have been playing the game with excited kiddos for many years with great success. Now, I want to share my game with you and make it available to other educators, parents and friends of the bees.

Part of what makes this game so fun, is that it's not your typical board game. It's not a board game at all. It's an imagination game that helps adults to facilitate educational play. Kids get to physically act their worker bee jobs while the queen bee (adult) guides them through colony life. Play it outside or in a large room so players can run, buzz and dance! The game works best in conjunction with a formal lesson on bees. It can be used to reinforce what they have learned in the lesson. This game is also great for teaching important life lessons like: leadership, problem solving and teamwork. Once the kids know how to play, the queen bee role can be handed off to one of the kids and they can be free to expand upon the game structure and get even more creative. 

I believe educating our little ones is the best way to ensure a bee-friendly future for our important pollinator friends. Let's help others create fun, educational learning opportunities in their communities by bringing this game to print! 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Last year, I did a small-run print of the game and shipped copies all over the world. The game was so popular, we sold out! I have reworked the design and am ready to do a large-scale print of the game, but I just don't have the funds to make it happen. I am constantly receiving emails and messages about when the game will be back in stock.

Your funding will allow me to reprint the game so that it can once again be available to bee lovers from around the globe! 

We need to raise...

  • $5,000 to pay for printing 

** Anything we raise over this goal, will be used to fund future educational products. I am always dreaming up new ways to educate people about bees!

In return for your support, we have some unique rewards! Not only can you pre-order the game, but you'll have the option to pick up some additional educational material that work in tandem with the game for educating kids. 

Risks & Challenges

If we don't meet our goal of $5,000, your contributions will be refunded. This is because I truly do not have the money to print this game without your help! 

If we do meet our goal, I do not anticipate any challenges other than potential shipping delays. It's going to be a lot of work packing and shipping all of your orders, but it will be so worth it!

What Does the Game Include?

The game comes with...

  • A felt "queen bee" crown (to be worn by the game leader)
  • A queen bee character pin (to be worn by the game leader)
  • A deck of 32 worker bee job cards 
  • 6 larger worker bee job presentation cards (5" X 7")
  • An instructional booklet. (The 5" X 8" booklet is designed to teach the game leader enough about bees to lead the game. The booklet also has alternate versions of the game to accommodate different settings and group sizes. Inside the booklet is a code that allows buyers to access a video of me explaining how the game is played and how/when to employ alternate versions of game play).

Other Ways You Can Help

Thanks for taking the time to learn about my game. If you can't contribute, you can still help by spreading the buzz. Please share this campaign with friends, parents, teachers and beekeepers you know. 

Reward Details

MINI POSTERS 

This comprehensive set of 20 mini posters includes a mix of posters from my existing Basic Set and Expansion Set already available in my online shop, but it has been updated with some new and improved images. Plus, it includes a brand new bonus poster featuring a diagram of the honey bee waggle dance. The posters are printed on high quality, thick poster stock paper. The 5 X 7" posters are designed to fit inside the game box for easy transport. Each one features an exciting image on one side and talking points on the other. Since the game is best played in combination with a formal lesson on bees, this poster set will give you everything you need  to keep kids engaged and learning. 

LARGE POSTERS

Bigger is better! If you're teaching a large group, these 13 X 19" posters will do the trick. Each one features an exciting image on one side and talking points on the other. This set includes all the images from my Basic Set already available in my online shop plus, a brand new bonus poster featuring a diagram of the honey bee waggle dance. The posters are printed on high quality, thick poster stock paper and have a UV coating to help protect against sun damage. Since the game is best played in combination with a formal lesson on bees, this poster set will give you everything you need  to keep kids engaged and learning. 

 

ONLINE BEEKEEPING CLASS

Start your beekeeping journey the easy way, with Hilary's online Introduction to Beekeeping Class! This class will teach you everything you need to know as a new beekeeper. It's organized and easy to understand so you don't get overwhelmed with information. Plus, you can stream this class more than once, making it a great tool for review. Hilary focuses on bee-centric beekeeping practices that put the needs of the bees first. Learn how the honey bee lives and why that information is vital to becoming an excellent beekeeper. She will also discuss different hive designs, what tools to buy, how to place your hive, how to acquire bees, honey harvesting methods, and common hive pests. Plus, tons of practical information about how to be successful as a beekeeper, what to look for during inspections and how to avoid common mistakes.

story:
What are we Doing?

  • My name is Henry Svec and I've lived on this farm for over 55 years.  We are now converting our farm from a regular cash crop operation to a Wildflower Bee Sanctuary.
  • The campaign is designed to replace 5 hives that we lost this past winter.  We believe that with our conversion of a cash crop farm to a Wildflower Bee Sanctuary, our bees will have a better chance of survival when not having to fight through conventional farming practices.
  • The addition of 5 hives will provide a quarter of a million bees the opportunity to live on our farm starting this spring.  By fall it is hoped that the 5 hives will have grown to 8 hives with an overall population of in excess of 500,000 bees.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are wanting to place an order for 5 new hives that have had one winter already in Ontario.  Our total ask is $1,500 that will all go to the purchase of those hives from an Ontario beekeeper.  Any extra funds raised will go to the purchase of more hives.
  • We have 2 levels of involvement for you.  For $35 you will receive access to our members only video blog page at www.wildflowerbeefarm.com   For the contribution of $500 you will receive access to the members only site, 4 pounds of honey when available and we will name one of our 5 new hives after you.  You will also receive regular personal emails/videos with updates on how your hive is doing.
  • If we achieve partial funding of our goal all of the funds will go to the purchase of hives ($300/hive)  which will be our cost this spring.

The Impact

By adding a million bees to the habitat (our long term goal), it will not only have a dramatic impact on the ecology, health and longevity of the environment, but ultimately, the health and more importantly, the happiness of the bees. 

When the bee farm officially launches spring 2020,  it will also be making a significant impact on the environment by offsetting its carbon footprint. By planting native wildflowers and clover, as well as the 15 acres of dense trees and bush we have, we will be able to sequester up to almost 54 tons of CO 2 per year.

Risks & Challenges

  • There is a risk that as we continually work to help our bees by using more conventional environmentally friendly methods, it may take some time (years) to provide a micro climate where they can thrive and survive winters and mite attacks.  We are working to find solutions by first helping them with a healthy environment and a place to live that will improve their chances of survival.
  • To solve this problem we will help our bees by providing them with different types of hives placed in different strategic locations around the 50 acre property.  We will also incorporate a combination of current and past proven bee helping strategies to learn and adapt as our bees tell us.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share our campaign with others, your friends and to your communities.
  • If you are able, this spring plant some bee friendly flowers that can help bees within your community.

If you are able, this spring plant some bee friendly flowers that can help bees within your community.

story:
Rykka here, I’ve recently released a new album called Kodiak, and I wrote the whole thing from the perspective of animals to try and bridge the mental gap that we’ve made between ourselves and nature - through music. Now that my album is released, it’s really important to me to spread the news about the benefits of PHYSICALLY getting into nature!

"The average North American child spends as few as 30 minutes playing outside each day, and more than seven hours in front of a screen. And yet, countless studies tell us that time outside makes children healthier, happier, more focused, more creative, more generous and, of course, better environmental stewards." *David Suzuki Foundation

NATURE ROCKS! 
On October 19, 2013 decide to set time aside to spend in nature!
Tell and Involve family and friends! Let the world around you know that you know that time in nature is time well spent. 

PARTICIPATE! 
- Take a walk with a friend through a forest
- Go bike riding along the beach
- Climb a mountain
- Skydive
- Meditate in your local public park or green area
Share your experiences online with #NatureRocks13

FUNDRAISE 
Collect pledges from people who support the cause, the money goes directly to the David Suzuki Foundation. This money will be used for work to preserve the environment as well as support many of the Connecting Youth with Nature Programs. 

PERKS

Check out the awesome perks generously donated by musicians, artists, writers and other amazing rad people who support the cause! 

GOAL 
Our goal is to raise $10,000 as a great foundation to preserve nature and to help develop the Connecting Youth with Nature Programs of the David Suzuki Foundation. 

If you’re not able to support the project with funding please remember that though it helps immensely in the larger picture, the most important thing to do is spend time in nature and involve as many people as possible! 

Spending time in nature is so crucial to our lives as individuals and as a community. Here are some interesting articles; 

The Nature Cure

Oprah's Health Benefits of Nature
Benefits of Exercising Outdoors

Development Under 3yrs of age

TV and Education

* IF YOU REQUIRE AN INCOME TAX RECEIPT PLEASE SUBMIT NAME, COMPLETE ADDRESS, PHONE NUMBER, AMOUNT & DATE OF DONATION TO SPATTEE@SHAW.CA 
* PLEASE NOTE - THE DAVID SUZUKI FOUNDATION CANNOT PROVIDE AN INCOME TAX RECEIPT IF A PERK IS SELECTED.  

THANK-YOU!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story: Hello everyone my name is Kashya. I am starting this campaign to help my family. Recently we were evicted from our home after going to court and fighting our case and even after paying rent and extra we were still evicted. We live with another family at the moment and it is very crowded so we're hoping ro raise enough to put a security deposit on an apartment. Recently i was laid off from my job at a medical center without warning and did not receive unemployment only two weeks of severance pay. I have been in the process of looking for a new job to help feed my family. I am starting this campaign because i am in desperate need of help for my three sisters and my brother they're 4,8,5,5. My mother is sick and i take care of her also. I want to be able to raise money to start over so we can get back to how we use to be. By helping us out with your donations you will bring joy to the children and help us be stress free until we get back on our feet. I know their are people out there that have a heart and will help us thats why my friend encourged me to start a campaign. At first i was embarassed but than i realized their is no reason to not share my story if we really need the help. We hope to reach the goal and make a better life for them. Thank you all for taking time out to read my story and god bless

story:
This is the final day to donate--help us protect one of the most unique marine habitats in the world!

We opened the Reserve on December 20th! Click here for local coverage of the opening celebration.

Help fund a project to protect sea turtles and other marine life while providing sustainable incomes to the local Bahamian economy.


For the last 3 years, on the Bahamian island of Eleuthera, the Burrows Family has been working with a team of local businesses and international conservationists to create Edwin's Turtle Lake Marine Reserve. This is the first privately managed marine reserve in the Bahamas, and is named after Mr. Edwin Burrows, who, along with his wife Gertrude, first homesteaded at the lake in the 1950's.

Sixty years later, Edwin Burrows' descendants are revitalizing the use and protection of Turtle Lake, by combining conservation efforts with sustainable income sources to manage the Reserve. This partnership is using Indiegogo to fund the launch of an Interpretive and Paddle Sports Center, the first step in a larger campaign to expand the size of the Reserve.


That is where you come in…. to help fund the establishment of this center of conservation and sustainable income, as a first step in making Edwin's Turtle Lake Marine Reserve a model for island and marine conservation throughout the Bahamas and beyond.

Your funding will enable our partnership to upgrade Edwin Burrows' original turtle hatching beach and turtle rearing alcove, build a small pier so renting kayaks and paddlers boards can access the lake, install a solar power system to energize these facilities, and add interpretative signs about the lake’s natural and cultural history for visitors to read.

   The Cultural and Natural History of Turtle Lake

At the center of this project is Turtle Lake and the Burrows Family.  Turtle Lake is a 43-acre inland saltwater lake nestled on the Caribbean side of Eleuthera, and connected to the Atlantic Ocean through a cave system underneath the island. Turtle Lake is just south of Governor's Harbour, Eleuthera's main settlement, and an important point of interest and entry for tourists from around the world.

Edwin Burrows, and his wife Gertrude, were early settlers in this part of Eleuthera. While raising 14 kids, they found time to open a bar on Cupids Cay, farm pineapples and vegetables, and raise turtles and fish. Edwin’s love of the sea and entrepreneurial spirit met a certain harmony at Turtle Lake. 

Sheltered from the wind, waves, and predators of the open sea, the lake was an ideal place to raise turtles and fish. Mr. Burrows placed sand along a section of shoreline to create a turtle-egg laying beach, and reared some of the baby turtles in a small rock-lined alcove nearby. When the turtles where large enough, he would release some in the ocean, and some back into the lake. 



In order to protect his use of, and vision for, Turtle Lake, Mr. Burrows secured a lease from the Bahamian Government for exclusive use of the lake. The lease granted him the rights to use Turtle Lake and some adjacent land for his conservation and income activities. It is that same marriage of economy and ecology that has inspired Edwin’s descendants to join forces with a team of local and international interests to formally establish Edwin's Turtle Lake Marine Reserve.

What makes Turtle Lake unique is that it is an inland saltwater lake, technically called a "blue hole." Among the worlds most unique and fragile marine environments, blue holes are inland caves or underwater sinkholes connected to the ocean. Turtle Lake is part of an inland cave system, whose salty waters come from the ocean. And yes, that means the level of Turtle Lake goes up and down with the tides. How cool is that?

Better yet, Turtle Lake is a place where paddle water sports and other forms of recreation can co-exist with the native marine life. This means Edwin's Turtle Lake Marine Reserve can be a sanctuary for sea turtles and other marine wildlife, a serene place for water recreation, and a source of environmentally sustainable income that supports Eleuthera's economy.



Upgrading the “Bottle Shack” and Other Facilities at Turtle Lake Reserve

Back in the day, Edwin Burrows built for his use what we now affectionately refer to as the Bottle Shack, because one side of his place was made with soda bottles – a common practice in those days to allow light into a building and add artistic flair. This historic building, when upgraded with solar generated electricity and a few other modern amenities paid for by this Indiegogo campaign, will serve as Reserve’s first center of activities (conservation, education, and recreation). 

Close to the Reserve’s “center”, we will build a pier off a recently cosntructed small deck, so that visitors can more easily access the lake with their kayaks and paddleboards, or watch wildlife from the end of the pier. As well, we will install more and better interpretive signs letting visitors know about the natural history and conservation of Turtle Lake.



This conservation and education center, as well as the paddle water sports sustainable business, will both be launched this December – even before this campaign is finished. We want to get started, as winter tourists are starting to arrive. Your funding will mean we can finish restoring all of the facilities Mr. Burrows built (the Bottle Shack, and the original turtle hatching beach and rearing alcove), as well as add the new structures and equipment, as soon as possible after the formal launch of the center and business. 

You won’t be paying for any salaries, only to help ensure a successful start to a new social enterprise that supports the mission of Edwin's Turtle Lake Marine Reserve. What's not to like about that? We think it is a great plan, one we are moving forward on because of our hope, even our confidence, that you will help us reach our goal of raising $17,500 to pay for these necessary upgrades and purchases.

We thank you for your support.... and so do the sea turtles and other wildlife of Turtle Lake!


Below you can more read about the opportunity and the challenge we are addressing through our long-term plans for Edwin's Turtle Lake Marine Reserve, and how your support will help us leverage an additional $500,000+ for the conservation of Turtle Lake’s critical shoreline habitat.


The Opportunity and the Challenge

Tourism in the Bahamas accounts for more than 60% of the country’s economy, and provides about 50% of all the jobs. Most of that revenue has come from periodic booms in construction of new hotels, resorts, and residences during the past 30+ years, development funded largely by investments and tourism dollars from the United States and Canada. Yet, this success has its challenges.

When the economies to the north went south between 2007-2011, the Bahamian economy shrank too. The tourism and construction industries have not fully recovered, which means fewer jobs for locals. Making matters worse for the island of Eleuthera, their large-scale tourism boom dropped off back in the 90’s, taking a lot of local jobs with it.

Second, this growth in hotels, resorts, and residences has reduced the amount of native habitat onshore, and large-scale tourism increases the human impact on the marine ecology. Part of what makes Edwin's Turtle Lake Marine Reserve so special is that, given its unique beauty and natural features, it has not been developed. At least not yet.


Possible Development on the Shores of Turtle Lake


There are, however, proposals to develop the eastern and western shoreline of Turtle Lake. A forty acre parcel on the eastern shoreline is slated for a large, multi-lot subdivision with 100 new homes. The likely sale and development of eight acres on the lake’s western shoreline would add insult to injury. These developments would have significant, undesired effects on Turtle Lake as a unique “blue hole” with its sensitive underground “plumbing”, as a wildlife sanctuary and breeding ground for green turtles, and as a highly desired Bahamian recreation and wilderness experience for locals and tourists alike.


                          The Team and the Plan

The team of people establishing Edwin's Turtle Lake Marine Reserve have a plan for ensuring Turtle Lake remains a natural sanctuary for both people and wildlife. Along with Edwin Burrows’ descendants, this team includes marine biologists and ecologists, geographers, architects, and hydrologists, organized by the Kinship Conservation Fellows to develop the strategy, summarized in this report.



Their work has been supported by the International League of Conservation Photographers, Kinship Conservation Foundation, Eleuthera-based The Island School, Woodbury University Graduate School of Architecture and New West Land Company, the non-profit Mermaid Islands, and Gillilan Associates. Finally, local businesses such as Pineapple Fields Resort are providing their expertise, connections, and support.



How Your Support Will Help Us Buy Those Lands
(or…. how $17,500 can secure $500,000+ for conservation)

A primary conservation goal of Edwin's Turtle Lake Marine Reserve is to purchase 48 acres along the lakeshore, and combine it with the Burrows’ existing land to enlarge the size of the reserve. Some of that land could be used to develop a conservation, environmental education, and retreat center that will support the reserve’s economic sustainability, and strengthen its conservation value. This plan is based on the concept of “market-based conservation,” where sustainably managed profit centers are embedded in a land and water conservation strategy.

The first phase of this plan is to develop an Interpretive and Paddle Sports Center on the Burrows’ land. This facility will serve as the foundation of an environmentally sustainable business model for the conservation and appropriate use of Turtle Lake.

With your support, we will be able to:

1)  launch a family-run business that provides low-impact water recreation activities to visitors from near and far;

2) provide interpretative signs and other educational materials that tell visitors about the natural and cultural history of this fascinating blue hole environment;

3)  expand the green sea turtle breeding and conservation program Edwin Burrows started more than 50 years ago.



What Your Money Will Specifically Pay For:

•Construction of a small pier off of the just installed deck at the Center, so visitors can launch their paddleboards and kayaks from the pier.

•Restore Edwin's turtle hatchling rearing alcove, a small area he created years ago so the lake’s juvenile green turtles could live while avoiding getting eaten by large fish in the lake. 

•Install interpretative signs and artwork that will tell the story of Turtle Lake’s natural and cultural history.

•Install solar power and hot water systems needed to run the Center.

•Purchase additional kayaks and paddle boards to be rented, and build a storage facility for this equipment.

With your support now, the Edwin's Turtle Lake Marine Reserve partnership will be able to build the foundation upon which it can first protect the watershed surrounding the Lake (through conservation easements and land purchases), and then establish a comprehensive program and facility for studying, conserving, and enjoying the blue hole ecosystem known as Turtle Lake.


How Could We use Funds Beyond our Indiegogo Goal?

If we are fortunate enough to raise more than $17,500, these extra funds will be dedicated to additional infrastructure upgrades, land and mangrove conservation efforts through establishing a fund for purchase and/or conservation easement.  In addition, we will conduct important research on Turtle Lake.  Since the lake is free of plastics, fishing gear and pollutants found in the ocean, it is an important reference condition for assessing turtle and fish life history and diets.  We will also investigate the feasibility of releasing juvenile turtles to augment threatened wild populations. 

Additional Infrastructure Stretch Goal: $15,000

The business plan calls for the construction of a gazebo at the end of the pier that we will build with this campaign.  The purpose of the gazebo is to provide a wildlife viewing and research platform, a lunch spot in the shade, a gathering spot and simply a place to drink in the beauty of Turtle Lake.


Think of yourself as investing in a start-up business (the Interpretative and Paddle Sports Center, run by the Burrows family) that – if all goes according to plan – will soon blossom into a model for island and marine conservation. We think that’s a darn good investment, where your dollars now can leverage an environmentally and economically beneficial program you can be proud of for decades to come.

Wouldn't it be great to be able to say, “I helped make the Edwin's Turtle Lake Marine Reserve a reality.” We think so. To that end, we thank you for whatever level of financial support you can give. And we look forward to including you in “our” mutual vision for Edwin's Turtle Lake Marine Reserve.


Additional Ways to Help:

  • Get the word about this campaign, visit and "like" our Facebook page.
  • Forward this campaign-link to supportive colleagues, friends and organizations.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Frequently Asked Questions:

Q: Where can I learn more about Turtle Lake and how did this project develop?
A:  You can visit the Turtle Lake website.  For additional background - In 2012 a diverse group conservation specialists affiliated with the Kinship Conservation Fellows program assembled at Turtle Lake and assessed relevant physical, socio-economic and market conditions and generated realistic and actionable conservation project ideas captured in a report.  
This was followed by a semester-long design studio on the Turtle Lake watershed by Woodbury University School of architecture.  The design studio team visited the Burrows Family in early 2014 to discuss project ideas.    


Q: What is a "blue hole"?

A: “Blue hole” is the term for water-bodies formed by limestone sinkholes, or submarine caves.  They are given their name because of the contrasting deep blue of the hole and the lighter blue of the shallows around them.  Some blue holes are located within the ocean, while others, such as Turtle Lake (pictured below), are inland systems more similar to lakes but are tidally connected - in the case of Turtle Lake, to the Atlantic Ocean though it sits closer to the Caribbean Sea coastline.  

Because of unique water quality and isolation of the cave system, each blue hole have their own distinctive biodiversity with National Geographic calling them "among the least studied and most threatened habitats on Earth".


Q: How did the sea turtles get into the lake? 

A: Mr. Edwin Burrows placed a few live turtles in the lake in the 1950's and 60's that were caught in his fishing nets.  He made a small beach along the shore and soon started raising turtles (see picture with notes from Edwin below).

Some of these original turtles continue to live in the lake today.  The rest of the turtles have been hatched and reared naturally in the lake at the beach we recently restored (picture below).


Q: Where is Turtle Lake and Eleuthera?

A: The island of Eleuthera lies 58 miles east of Nassau, Bahamas and 250 miles southeast of the southern tip of Florida, USA. 


Q: How did Mr. Burrows secure the rights to the lake?

A: He got a lease from the Bahamian government to use the lake.  The lease is renewed annually by the Burrows Family.  

Q: What socio-economic impacts can I expect with my contribution to the campaign?

A:  One of our criteria’s for project success is the ability to generate jobs and income in an economically challenged community.  We feel this will be realized within months of opening the Reserve.  A larger strategy that we are engaged in with other local partners is to re-brand Governor’s Harbor and Eleuthera as a sustainable tourism destination targeting active life-style tourists, the fastest growing segment of travelers from North America and Europe.

Q: How do I become more involved with the project besides monetary support?

A:  We are always recruiting team members to join us on our project development visits, with our next research trip scheduled for March 29 – April 11.  On that trip we will be focusing on conservation science, (marine, terrestrial/botanical, birds, mapping, planning) and supporting the staff at the Reserve with business development, training and mentoring.  We have found it easy to incorporate citizen scientists so anyone with a sincere interest in our work is welcome to join us.

Turtle Lake


There
are, however, proposals to develop the eastern and western shoreline of Turtle Lake. A forty acre parcel on the eastern
shoreline is slated for a large, multi-lot subdivision with 100 new homes. The
likely sale and development of eight acres on the lake’s western shoreline would
add insult to injury. These developments would have significant, undesired
effects on Turtle Lake as a unique “blue hole” with its sensitive underground
“plumbing”, as a wildlife sanctuary and breeding ground for green turtles, and
as a highly desired Bahamian recreation and wilderness experience for locals
and tourists alike.

                          The Team and the Plan
The team of people establishing Edwin's Turtle Lake Marine Reserve have a
plan for ensuring Turtle Lake remains a natural sanctuary for both people and
wildlife. Along with Edwin Burrows’ descendants, this team includes marine biologists and ecologists, geographers, architects,
and hydrologists, organized by the Kinship Conservation Fellows to develop the
strategy, summarized in this report.






Their work has been supported by the
International League of Conservation Photographers, Kinship Conservation Foundation, Eleuthera-based The Island School, Woodbury University Graduate School of Architecture and New West Land Company, the non-profit Mermaid Islands, and Gillilan
Associates. Finally, local businesses such as Pineapple Fields Resort are providing their expertise,
connections, and support.




How Your Support Will Help Us Buy
Those Lands(or…. how $17,500 can secure $500,000+ for conservation)



A primary conservation goal of Edwin's Turtle Lake
Marine Reserve is to purchase 48 acres along the lakeshore, and combine it with
the Burrows’ existing land to enlarge the size of the reserve. Some of that
land could be used to develop a conservation, environmental education, and
retreat center that will support the reserve’s economic sustainability, and
strengthen its conservation value. This plan is based on the concept of
“market-based conservation,” where sustainably managed profit centers are
embedded in a land and water conservation strategy. 
The first phase of this plan is to
develop an Interpretive and Paddle Sports Center on the Burrows’ land. This facility will serve as the foundation of an environmentally
sustainable business model for the conservation and appropriate use of Turtle
Lake. 
With your support, we will be able to:
1) 
launch a family-run business that provides low-impact
water recreation activities to visitors from near and far;
2) provide interpretative signs and other educational
materials that tell visitors about the natural and cultural history of this fascinating
blue hole environment; 
3) 
expand the green sea turtle breeding
and conservation program Edwin Burrows started more than 50 years
ago.





What Your Money Will Specifically Pay
For:

•Construction of a small pier off of the just installed deck at the Center, so visitors can launch their paddleboards and kayaks from the pier.
•Restore Edwin's turtle hatchling rearing alcove, a small area he created years ago so the lake’s juvenile green turtles could live while avoiding getting eaten by large fish in the lake. 
•Install interpretative signs and artwork that will tell the story of Turtle Lake’s natural and cultural history.
•Install solar power and hot water systems needed to run the Center.
•Purchase additional kayaks and paddle boards to be rented, and build a storage facility for this equipment.
With your support now, the Edwin's Turtle Lake Marine Reserve partnership will be able to build the foundation upon which it can first protect the watershed surrounding the Lake (through conservation easements and land purchases), and then establish a comprehensive program and facility for studying, conserving, and enjoying the blue hole ecosystem known as Turtle Lake.

How Could We use Funds Beyond our Indiegogo Goal?
If we are fortunate enough to raise more than $17,500, these extra funds will be dedicated to additional infrastructure upgrades, land and mangrove conservation efforts through establishing a fund for purchase and/or conservation easement.  In addition, we will conduct important research on Turtle Lake.  Since the lake is free of plastics, fishing gear and pollutants found in the ocean, it is an important reference condition for assessing turtle and fish life history and diets.  We will also investigate the feasibility of releasing juvenile turtles to augment threatened wild populations. 
Additional Infrastructure Stretch Goal: $15,000
The business plan calls for the construction of a gazebo at the end of the pier that we will build with this campaign.  The purpose of the gazebo is to provide a wildlife viewing and research platform, a lunch spot in the shade, a gathering spot and simply a place to drink in the beauty of Turtle Lake.




Think of yourself as investing in a start-up business (the Interpretative and Paddle Sports Center, run by the Burrows family) that – if all goes according to plan – will soon blossom into a model for island and marine conservation. We think that’s a darn good investment, where your dollars now can leverage an environmentally and economically beneficial program you can be proud of for decades to come.




Wouldn't it be great to be able to say, “I helped make the Edwin's Turtle Lake Marine Reserve a reality.” We think so. To that end, we thank you for whatever level of financial support you can give. And we look forward to including you in “our” mutual vision for Edwin's Turtle Lake Marine Reserve.






Additional Ways to Help:
 
Get the word about this campaign, visit and "like" our Facebook page.
Forward this campaign-link to supportive colleagues, friends and organizations. Use the Indiegogo share tools! 
 Frequently Asked Questions:Q: Where can I learn more about Turtle Lake and how did this project develop?A:  You can visit the Turtle Lake website.  For additional background - In 2012 a diverse group conservation specialists affiliated with the Kinship Conservation Fellows program assembled at Turtle Lake and assessed relevant physical, socio-economic and market conditions and generated realistic and actionable conservation project ideas captured in a report.  This was followed by a semester-long design studio on the Turtle Lake watershed by Woodbury University School of architecture.  The design studio team visited the Burrows Family in early 2014 to discuss project ideas.    


Q: What is a "blue hole"?
A: “Blue hole” is the term for water-bodies formed by limestone sinkholes, or submarine caves.  They are given their name because of the contrasting deep blue of the hole and the lighter blue of the shallows around them.  Some blue holes are located within the ocean, while others, such as Turtle Lake (pictured below), are inland systems more similar to lakes but are tidally connected - in the case of Turtle Lake, to the Atlantic Ocean though it sits closer to the Caribbean Sea coastline.  Because of unique water quality and isolation of the cave system, each blue hole have their own distinctive biodiversity with National Geographic calling them "among the least studied and most threatened habitats on Earth".Q: How did the sea turtles get into the lake? A: Mr. Edwin Burrows placed a few live turtles in the lake in the 1950's and 60's that were caught in his fishing nets.  He made a small beach along the shore and soon started raising turtles (see picture with notes from Edwin below).Some of these original turtles continue to live in the lake today.  The rest of the turtles have been hatched and reared naturally in the lake at the beach we recently restored (picture below).Q: Where is Turtle Lake and Eleuthera?A: The island of Eleuthera lies 58 miles east of Nassau, Bahamas and 250 miles southeast of the southern tip of Florida, USA. Q: How did Mr. Burrows secure the rights to the lake?A: He got a lease from the Bahamian government to use the lake.  The lease is renewed annually by the Burrows Family.  Q: What socio-economic impacts can I expect with my
contribution to the campaign?
A:  One of our criteria’s for project success is the
ability to generate jobs and income in an economically challenged
community.  We feel this will be realized within months of
opening the Reserve.  A larger strategy that we are engaged in with other
local partners is to re-brand Governor’s Harbor and Eleuthera as a sustainable tourism
destination targeting active life-style tourists, the fastest growing segment
of travelers from North America and Europe.
Q: How do I become more involved with the project besides
monetary support?
A:  We are always recruiting team members to join us on
our project development visits, with our next research trip scheduled for March 29
– April 11.  On that trip we will be focusing on conservation
science, (marine, terrestrial/botanical, birds, mapping, planning) and
supporting the staff at the Reserve with business development, training and
mentoring.  We have found it easy to incorporate citizen scientists so
anyone with a sincere interest in our work is welcome to join us.

story:
From Senior Project to Reality

Pure Life is a company created by four high school Senior Engineering students at Tyner Academy in Chattanooga, TN. In a collaborative effort with the Launch Chattanooga High School Entrepreneurship Program, our business was born.

Pure Life is centered around creating effective, and efficient methods of cleaning. In funding Pure Life you will help with the development and manufacturing of our first product, GiroClean (Pronounced Jī-ro Clean). The GiroClean is an auto-filtering mop bucket that removes the yucky debris from the water at the press of a button as you mop. This not only saves you precious time and energy, but it also recycles and reuses water which benefits the environment and lends itself to green living.

We are looking to raise $3000 to put toward further development and manufacturing of our product. Your donation to our business tells us that you believe in our product, and that you share in our belief that saving water is essential in creating a better environment. Even if we don't meet our goal, every penny counts and will be greatly appreciated. 


What We Need - What's In it For You

Your contribution to Pure Life will enable us to take our prototype to a manufacturer to begin production of the GiroClean.

We don’t want you to leave with nothing, so we have partnered with a local designer to bring you fun perks for your contribution! We have everything from a $1 perk up to an exclusive YOU GET IT ALL! Package for the big contributor. But, don’t let those levels fence you in - you may give any amount you choose. Go on, test us, the sky is the limit. 


What Impact Can You Make? 

Your contribution will allow us to go beyond the competition phase of the Launch Chattanooga project and allow us to actually produce this product. Rather than leave this as a Senior Project, your contribution will allow us to move forward and actually create this product. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? That doesn’t mean you can't help! Help us spread the word. Use the Indiegogo share tools to help us spread the word. 


Please watch this video for more information about the Launch Chattanooga High School Entrepreneurship Program.

story:
Change starts with a single thread: #16034238


Imagine being part of the leading edge of community driven discovery and crowd funded knowledge pertaining to "the first fungus species to be able to survive exclusively on polyurethane. "

  • I am ReggieJenkins, and I am passionate about mycology
  • I have browsed the Shroomery for years, and have had my feet wet in the fields of mycological studies for about two years  
A few nights ago, I curiously entered into the search box at Google.com "Fungi that eats plastic". This lead me to a thread on the Shroomery aged at just over 2.5 years in time discussing the study of this fungus, and I was hoping it would lead to a culture. I read the whole thing, and upon arriving at the last post in the thread I noticed it was responded to only a few moments ago...so I chimed in, expressing my willingness to help find a culture in any way I could. 

A few users expressed their willingness to contribute financially to get a culture circulating after one had been located (thanks MrCloudy) at a cost of $354 with no shipping cost. 

The culture (if ordered today) would not be expected to ship until February. It is my intentions to obtain a culture and send it off to the most scientifically capable hands (someone with the proper lab equipment) and get it divvied up to all contributing parties to disperse and study this fascinating specimen. 

IndieGoGo has a $500 minimum - any remaining funds after purchase will be used to ensure that the specimen arrives safely in capable hands, as well as covering the additional costs of creating additional slants/cultures and the shipping of these to interested parties. 

Thanks for your help, the Shroomery thanks you!

Peace, love, and good vibes everyone! Thanks for your help. 

Update 11/19/2014:

People are confused by what's going on - and that's understandable. Here's a quick recap.

After I created the campaign, an anonymous culture bank reached out to donate cultures as rewards. IndieGoGo does not allow me to modify the perks after they have been claimed by one person.

It was decided by myself and Alan that at $20+ they should receive an agar wedge of whichever culture they selected in addition to their sample of the Pestalotiopsis microspora.

The Pestalotiopsis is being ordered from the ATCC on December 3rd. Once expanded - the samples of this will be sent out. 

IF you have donated, please see the updates section and make sure you email ReggieJenkins@HushMail.com if you haven't already. 

PLEASE CHECK THIS THREAD:  http://www.shroomery.org/forums/showflat.php?Ca... for updates in between the status reports from IndieGoGo.

story:
Who are we?

 

The Kite Collective is a group of kite-makers and artists based in New York City. We offer kites to the public in creative, interactive ways.

 


 

Why Kites?

 

Kites are a means of disconnecting from our smart phones and reconnecting with the sky, ourselves and the world around us. Kite flying is our way of navigating the omnipresent forces of the wind and "looking up" toward a vibrant, resilient community landscape.

 

The Kite Machine Project

 

The Kite Machine is a travelling kite dispenser that provides miniature kites for the public. The first installation took place at local taco joint Rockaway Taco in NYC last Summer. The project went swimmingly and we were able to provide kites to over 600 people in the Rockaways. Locals and tourists alike all pitched in to help make kites for the machine, telling stories and having laughs along the way and building community from the ground up. 

 

 

 

 

This year, we're bringing the Kite Machine to Governor's Island. Our goal is to see 5,000 kites in the sky!!!

 

 

 

Governor's Island

 

Not only is Governor's Island one of New York City's historic treasures, but it is the perfect place to fly a kite — there are acres of open green space to run and plenty of wind off the Harbor. Governor's Island is open from May through September on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. During this time, the machine will be stocked with easy-to-fly kite kits for the public.

 

 

We will be stocking the machine each week with these awesome, reusable kite kits by Lindsay Powers. "The Mini Kite Kit" comes with a compact, colourful kite that unfolds to a standard-size kite for all to enjoy. Fun for kids and adults alike, this nostalgic kit will bring you back to the happy-go-lucky days of your childhood and chase away your worries in no time. 

 

Miniature Kite Kit

 

 

PERKS!

 

 

Here are some of the perks you'll be getting in exchange for your contribution to the Kite Machine:

 

Handmade Kites by the Kite Collective 

 

Left, ROCK series kite. Right, SLED series kite.

 

Limited-edition Kite Pins 


Various kite pins designed by famed artists and kite-makers.

 

Kite Art Books

 

Left, Kites: Paper Wings Over Japan. Right, Japanese Kite Prints

 

Donations are tax-deductible through our Fiscal Sponsor organization, 501(c)(3) Fractured Atlas. If we exceed our goal, we can continue the project for longer, conduct more workshops and have more kites in the sky for all to enjoy.

 

Arts Programming

 

We plan to do a series of kite-making workshops at Governor’s Island every weekend. Workshops include a kite-making demonstration, kite-making materials, guest speakers and are available to the public free of charge.

 

 

In the past, we have taught kite-making classes at Trade School, hosted at the Museum of Art & Design, Built in Brooklyn Craft Fair and NurtureArt's Lawn School.

 

Other Ways to Support

 

Help us keep the project growing by contributing what you can.  Please follow us on Facebook and share the project with your friends and loved ones. For volunteer opportunities, contact kitecollective@gmail.com.  

 

 

 

For more information:

cargocollective.com/kitecollective | kitecollective@gmail.com

story:
Introduction

Grow Where You Are is a dynamic full service provider in the field of local food systems.  We partner with organizations and individuals to bring food abundance to communities and those who value real food. We design, install, and maintain multiple public and private spaces where food is produced using Agro-Ecological principles.  We have been training residents in this dynamic form of urban agriculture for over ten years.  Grow Where You Are provides strategic support for community based organizations such as the West Atlanta Watershed Alliance and Retrofit A Million, as well as, local food enterprises such as Maitu Foods, ThirdMoon Botanica, Cherokee Moon Mixology and R.O.O.T.S. Urban Farmer's Exchange.


Atlanta Black Cracker's Lab Camp

We are creating an outdoor laboratory to explore the revitalizing influence of a living growing space and observatory in the Bush Mountain Community. Our laboratory is situated in the Historical Atlanta Black Cracker Field. In the 1920s and 1930s during the height of the National Negro League and deep segregation in the south, the Atlanta Black Crackers utilized this site. Serving as a community center this space created an atmosphere of connectivity and fellowship through outdoor recreation. 

Development of this currently under-utilized 2 acre site will include an interactive native planting and historical vegetable and fruit mini-farm. Additions will be made to the existing campground which holds the annual Great American Backyard Campout. There will be information about the historical significance of the land as well as an art installation tribute to the Atlanta Black Crackers Baseball Team.



Strategic Plan

The site will be cleared of invasive brush and debris.  The organic material will be gathered and burned in the newly constructed fire pit which will be located at the site where the annual Great American Backyard Campout is held.  Using existing clay soil we will construct an outdoor oven for bread making and food prep. The oven area will serve as the first of three focus ‘laboratory’ stations where visitors learn through experiencing transformation and witnessing the elements.  With assistance from Urban Construction and re-using tires that have been dumped for years, on-site, we will construct an observation deck approximately 10’ tall.  This observation deck will serve as the second ‘laboratory’ station where observation is guided with signage a telescope, windsock and weather turbine.  During the fall we will plant a variety of native, medicinal plants in the Northwest area where wildflowers are grown in Spring and summer.  Along pathways and border areas we will plant small cluster orchards and fruiting shrubs such as blueberry, pomegranate, pawpaw, chestnut, persimmon, plum and apple.  The final ‘laboratory’ space will be a commemorative art plaque sharing historical information about the site as well as geographic, ecological and social significance of the place.  We would like to utilize technology such as QRC codes where campers can access a site with more in depth historical information, local weather forecasts and an updated community calendar of events.


The Impact

Over the past (4) growing seasons and 2+ years that we have been developing and programming at the Urban Garden Resiliency Oasis (UGRO), each of the (32) youth service learning experiences we stewarded included a facilitated guided hike through the Historic Black Cracker Field and into the woods of the 26 acre Outdoor Activity Center (OAC). These transformative experiences provided at least 400+ youth a chance to learn about habitat management and improvement, trail stewardship and building, and environmental monitoring.

After witnessing the reactions of the youth and overseeing the expansion of the Oakland City Hartnett Community garden adjacent to UGRO, expanding the wildlife habitat and agricultural space into the Black Cracker Field is a natural outgrowth. To  attract even more urban families of SW Atlanta to explore green-spaces, we propose creating a unique wildlife habitat and natural growing space. The field will be transformed into a beautiful and aesthetically enhanced outdoor classroom that will be minimally manicured with large fields of traditional time period crops as well as flowers and possible fruit trees and shrubs as the border. The Black Cracker Field will become the crown jewel in the hidden gem of the OAC and will become a premier destination area for people of all backgrounds to come for renewal and inspiration. It will become renowned for its landscape and horticulture design provided by Grow Where You Are LLC., and will feature wild medicinal plants and native growing crops that grew on the field during the 19th and 20th centuries.

Gaining a sense of place can be one of the most empowering things that the modern human can do.  In a world where we are indoors most of our time, travel at high speeds, and focus on electronic devices, many of us are out of touch with our environments and our own creativity.  For a community that is half vacant and underinvested this outdoor space will offer the opportunity to examine an alternative way to develop communities through seasonal gatherings and beautification.  The added bonus of food production will serve as inspiration for residents to view open spaces and their own property as rich places for growing food.


Other Ways You Can Help

You want to help, but may not be able to do it financially? No problem, there are a number of ways to help with this initiative, one of the first is to get the word out. Share with your friends, co-workers, social media followers, wherever and whoever you can think of. Help us spread the word about what Grow Where You Are (GWYA) is doing, and don't forget Indiegogo has awesome share tools to help spread the message as well. Volunteers! We value the work and the energy that volunteers bring to the collective. Children's groups and learning communities are a valuable part of what and why we do the work that we do. Bring out your community groups to join us in the hands on service learning opportunities  that GWYA offers. Come out to our farm, The Good Shepherd AgroEcology Center and markets to see just what we are doing and how you can be a part of it. For more information, visit us at Know Your Grower Atlanta.
